question: [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/prover_dependencies.rs] [Function: download_dependency()] [Binary Integrity After Download] After update_binary() completes at lines 132, 151, 172, is there any verification that the downloaded binary matches expected hash values before it's used, or could partial downloads or corruption lead to execution of malformed binaries? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/prover_dependencies.rs] [Function: download_dependency()] [GitHub API Rate Limiting Bypass] Can an attacker exploit GitHub API authentication or rate limiting weaknesses in update_binary() to cause the installer to download binaries from attacker-controlled GitHub releases or alternative endpoints? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/prover_dependencies.rs] [Function: execute()] [Concurrent Installation Race] When execute() calls download_dependency().await at line 217, can multiple concurrent installations of prover dependencies create race conditions where different installation processes interfere with each other, causing corrupted binaries or inconsistent environment variable state? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/prover_dependencies.rs] [Function: download_dependency()] [Multi-Binary TOCTOU] Between installing boogie at line 132, z3 at line 152, and cvc5 at line 173, can an attacker exploit the time window to modify previously installed binaries or environment variables, causing inconsistent prover tool versions? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/prover_dependencies.rs] [Function: download_dependency()] [Async Cancellation Safety] If the async download_dependency() function is cancelled or panics between binary installations (lines 122-173), can this leave the system in an inconsistent state with only some prover tools installed and environment variables partially set? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/prover_dependencies.rs] [Function: install_binary()] [Directory Lock Missing] When creating DependencyInstaller instances at lines 189-199 for multiple tools, is there any locking mechanism to prevent concurrent writes to the same install_dir, potentially causing file corruption or race conditions? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/prover_dependencies.rs] [Constants: BOOGIE_EXE, Z3_EXE] [DLL Hijacking Attack] On Windows, when installing boogie.exe (line 34) or z3.exe (line 43), does the installer validate that no malicious DLLs are present in the installation directory or PATH that could be loaded by these executables through DLL search order hijacking? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/prover_dependencies.rs] [Constants: *_EXE] [Executable Extension Bypass] Can an attacker exploit the conditional compilation that sets different executable extensions on Windows vs Unix (lines 33-36, 42-45) to bypass security checks by supplying executables without the .exe extension on Windows or with wrong extensions? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/prover_dependencies.rs] [Function: download_dependency()] [Windows PATH Pollution] When setting environment variables for boogie.exe and z3.exe on Windows through add_env_var(), can an attacker exploit Windows PATH resolution behavior to cause the system to execute identically-named malicious executables from higher-priority PATH locations? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/prover_dependencies.rs] [Function: download_dependency()] [Partial Installation State] If install_binary() fails for z3 at line 151 after successfully installing boogie at line 132, does the function rollback the boogie installation, or does it leave the system in an inconsistent state with only partial prover dependencies installed? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/prover_dependencies.rs] [Function: download_dependency()] [Error Propagation Weakness] When check_version_is_compatible() returns an error at lines 116, 135, or 156, does the error properly propagate to prevent subsequent installation attempts, or could partial error handling allow installation of incompatible tool versions? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/prover_dependencies.rs] [Function: install_binary()] [Eprintln Error Hiding] At line 204, critical errors from add_env_var() are only printed with eprintln!() instead of being propagated as errors - can this allow the installation to appear successful while environment variables are incorrectly set, causing silent failures in later prover operations? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/prover_dependencies.rs] [Function: download_dependency()] [Context Error Information Leak] Do the .with_context() calls at line 111 leak sensitive information about the file system structure or installation paths in error messages that could help an attacker map the system? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/prover_dependencies.rs] [Function: install_binary()] [Version Match String Injection] When passing version_match_string values like 'Boogie program verifier version ' (line 129), 'Z3 version ' (line 148), or 'This is cvc5 version ' (line 169) to DependencyInstaller, can an attacker exploit insufficient input validation to inject regex metacharacters or command injection payloads? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/prover_dependencies.rs] [Function: install_binary()] [Version Option String Injection] Can the version_option_string parameters like '/' (line 128), '--' (line 147, 168) be exploited if passed unsanitized to command execution, allowing injection of additional command-line arguments or shell metacharacters? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/prover_dependencies.rs] [Function: install_binary()] [Environment Variable Name Injection] When passing BOOGIE_EXE_ENV, Z3_EXE_ENV, CVC5_EXE_ENV (lines 130, 149, 170) to the installer, does the code validate that these are legitimate environment variable names, or could shell injection occur through malicious env var names? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/prover_dependencies.rs] [Constants: REPO_OWNER, REPO_NAME] [Hardcoded Repository Hijacking] The hardcoded REPO_OWNER='aptos-labs' and REPO_NAME='prover-dependency' at lines 27-28 create a single point of failure - if these values are somehow mutable or can be influenced by environment variables, could an attacker redirect downloads to a malicious repository? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/prover_dependencies.rs] [Constants: TARGET_*_VERSION] [Version Freeze Attack] Are the TARGET_BOOGIE_VERSION ('3.5.1'), TARGET_Z3_VERSION ('4.11.2'), and TARGET_CVC5_VERSION ('0.0.3') constants at lines 30, 39, 50 updated regularly, or could outdated versions contain known vulnerabilities that attackers can exploit? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/prover_dependencies.rs] [Constants: *_EXE_ENV] [Environment Variable Conflict] Can an attacker pre-set BOOGIE_EXE (line 32), Z3_EXE (line 41), or CVC5_EXE (line 53) environment variables to point to malicious binaries before the installer runs, causing add_env_var() to detect a conflict but still allowing the malicious binary to be used? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/prover_dependencies.rs] [Constants: *_BINARY_NAME] [Name Collision Attack] Could an attacker exploit the binary names 'boogie' (line 29), 'z3' (line 38), and 'cvc5' (line 48) by pre-installing malicious executables with these exact names in system PATH locations that take precedence over the installed versions? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/prover_dependencies.rs] [Function: download_dependency()] [CVC5 Unix-Only Installation Gap] The CVC5 installation at lines 154-174 only occurs on Unix platforms (cfg(unix)) - can an attacker exploit this platform-specific behavior to cause inconsistent prover tool availability across platforms, potentially bypassing security checks that assume cvc5 is always available? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/prover_dependencies.rs] [Constants: CVC5 cfg gates] [Conditional Compilation Attack] The CVC5-related constants at lines 47-55 use #[cfg(not(target_os = 'windows'))] - can an attacker exploit build-time configuration to include Windows CVC5 support maliciously or remove Unix CVC5 support to weaken verification capabilities? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/prover_dependencies.rs] [Function: download_dependency()] [Platform-Specific Version Mismatch] When different platforms install different tool versions due to platform-specific code paths, could this lead to inconsistent verification results where Move code verified on one platform fails on another, bypassing security properties? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/prover_dependencies.rs] [Function: command_name()] [Command Name Spoofing] The command_name() method returns 'InstallProverDependencies' at line 213 - can an attacker exploit this identifier in CLI argument parsing or logging to masquerade as legitimate prover installation while performing malicious operations? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/prover_dependencies.rs] [Function: execute()] [Async Execution Safety] When execute() calls self.download_dependency().await at line 217, are there any safeguards against concurrent executions that could cause race conditions or resource exhaustion through repeated installation attempts? (Medium)
